definition: Zi Gong or Duanmu Ci 端木賜|端木赐[Duan1 mu4 Ci4] (520 BC-), disciple of Confucius
(noun suffix)

son/child/seed/egg/small thing/1st earthly branch: 11 p.m.-1 a.m., midnight, 11th solar month (7th December to 5th January), year of the Rat/Viscount, fourth of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/ancient Chinese compass point: 0° (north)
surname Gong
to offer tribute/tribute/gifts

sentences.english: Looking at it, Zi Gong felt it was out of convenance.
sentences.chinese: 子贡看见这样的行径，大不以为然。

sentences.english: After class, Zi Gong found a chance to see Confucius alone.
sentences.chinese: 孔子的忧虑，全让子贡看在眼里。

sentences.english: But if only one was chosen, what would be in the above two?
sentences.chinese: 子贡就问，不能有三样东西，只要两样呢？

sentences.english: In the name of a disciple of Confucius, Zi Gong asked to see Laodan.
sentences.chinese: 子贡以孔子弟子的身份往老聃处求见。

sentences.english: Zi Gong felt that they were irrational so he went back.
sentences.chinese: 子贡觉得这些人不可理喻，因此就回去了。

sentences.english: Zi Gong detected Confucius's worry from his face.
sentences.chinese: 孔子的忧虑，全让子贡看在眼里。

sentences.english: Zi-gong asked, "What do you think of me?"
sentences.chinese: 子贡问道，“我是怎样的人呢？”

sentences.english: "On coming out, Zi-gong said, "The Master does not support him.
sentences.chinese: 子贡退出来，对冉有说，“老师不会帮助卫君。”

definition: Zi Lu (542-480 BC), disciple of Confucius 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3], also known as Ji Lu 季路[Ji4 Lu4]
Yan Hui (521-481 BC), disciple of Confucius, also known as Yan Yuan 顏淵|颜渊[Yan2 Yuan1]
Yan Yuan (521-481 BC), disciple of Confucius 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3], also known as 顏回|颜回[Yan2 Hui2]
Confucius (551-479 BC), Chinese thinker and social philosopher, also known as 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3]
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
Duanmu Ci (520 BC-446 BC), disciple of Confucius, also known as Zi Gong 子貢|子贡[Zi3 Gong4]
Lu, vassal state at the time of the Zhou Dynasty 周朝|周朝[Zhou1 chao2], located in the southwest of present-day Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1], birthplace of Confucius
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏婴, hero of book 晏子春秋
Zengzi (505-435 BC), student of Confucius, presumed editor or author of Confucian classic the Great Learning 大學|大学[Da4 xue2]
Mencius (c. 372-c. 289 BC), Confucian philosopher second only to Confucius/book of the same name, one of the classics of Confucianism
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
Zai Yu (522-458 BC), disciple of Confucius
Zi Chan (?-522 BC), statesman and philosopher during the Spring and Autumn period
Confucius
Lord Menchang of Qi, Chancellor of Qi and of Wei during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
the lord of Lu (who declined to employ Confucius)
